reviews.review_msg: Praise is an engaging prof! She always tries to go above and beyond to create fun lectures. The content is the difficult part. There is a lot to memorize and the audit process is quite complicated. As such, the prof and (dry) textbook are your best friends. Exams are reasonable; MC are a bit tricky, long answers very similar to in-class activities.

Hands down the best professor I've ever had at SFU. Explained concepts well during lectures and went the extra mile with slides and in-class activities to facilitate engagement (Kahoot, in-class problems). If you take BUS 426 (Audit), I highly recommend taking her class.

Very ambiguous way of teaching. Asks you very obscure questions on auditing and then penalize you for not having the same answers that he had though. Multiple choice questions are ill prepared and lack objectivity. Overall not a good teacher.
Did not like his teaching at all. Only This guy has the ability to take a relatively easy course and make it exorbitantly hard to pass.

The most subjective marker I have ever had at SFU. Will give you a grade based on what mood he's in that day. Assignment/group project criteria is unclear, and he will give you a mark on the group project without telling you why you got that mark. If you have experience in audit/accounting, you'll do well cause the exam Qs are open-ended.

Grading criteria isn't clear at all. Multiple people from my class had emailed him weeks in advance to the final and he provided no clarification whatsoever. No practice problems were assigned throughout the semester, and he refused to provide any when asked. This made studying for the final even more difficult due to practical inexperience.
Passionate about course, overall a nice guy
He is not a good professor. He is vague about the grading skeeme. Avoid him.
He does not give clear guidelines as to what to expect in the exam. Overall not a good prof.

Dana is an expert in the field of auditing. He is very approachable and cares about all his students. He does an excellent job helping students learn about the basic framework and principles of auditing. Midterm (memorization) and final (application) were different.  Would be helpful if he used a mic. And written report requirements were unclear.

Professor Grieg is a very knowledgeable and passionate  individual about the subjects he teaches. With years of real world business experience he was able to bring the subject to life and give unique scenarios/cases of how the course was relevant. As a class of future CPA's we were all able to gain a healthy respect for being ethical & professional
Nice guy. He likes teaching and it shows.

Dana is the best professors I've had at SFU. He keeps his lectures interesting by sharing his field experience and talking about real-life challenges that the students might experience in their future careers. His exams and assignments are not easy, but he prepares the students very well for the challenges. Just follow his advice and you'll do well

He's a very good prof and tries to explain everything clearly. What I liked most about his class is that he doesn't give exams based on dead theory/memory-based questions. Instead, he gives you cases and you are expected to answer accordingly. Very useful if you plan on taking CASB. One of the best in SFU!

Anne is possibly one of the best profs that SFU has to offer. She is extremely knowledgeable with the course material and does whatever it takes to ensure that her students succeed in her class. You should definitely take a course with her if you have the opportunity!
I took Bus 251 and 426 with her. She's THE reason why it's worth studying accounting at SFU. I regret not taking 420 with her.

Her auditing class is amazing. Yes material is dull but she explains concepts using cases rather than textbook. Only need to read certain chapters (just read the important ones) and all the cases and slides for exams. No memo on my mt. Wish she taught all my acct courses
